message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and a previous myocardial infarction, which puts him at risk for mitral valve prolapse. The physical examination findings of a mid-to-late systolic murmur at the apex also point towards mitral valve prolapse. The other options are less likely based on the patient’s history and physical examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and panic attacks, all of which are risk factors for mitral valve prolapse. The patient also exhibits a mid-to-late systolic murmur best heard at the apex, which is characteristic of mitral valve prolapse. Pulmonary valve regurgitation typically presents with a diastolic murmur. Tricuspid valve stenosis presents with a diastolic murmur along the left sternal border. Pulmonary valve stenosis presents with a systolic ejection click and a holosystolic murmur.
